title: Bank bosses lament their dwindling pay packets
text:
Other CBA executives received short-term bonuses that ranged between 31 per cent to 52 per cent of their maximum entitlements.

The chairmen of CBA's major rivals – Westpac, the National Australia Bank and the ANZ Bank – will be watching the shareholder support for CBA's latest remuneration report with mixed feelings.

They'll be aware it has created a strong expectation among their own shareholders that they'll follow CBA's lead and show a similar enthusiasm for pruning the short-term bonuses of their top executives.

And all three chairmen will no doubt still be nursing searing memories of the humiliation of their annual general meetings late last year, when shareholders voiced their fury at their failure to slash the bonuses paid out to their top executives.

The shareholder mutiny meant that three of the country's four largest banks suffered a first "strike", a vote of more than 25 per cent against its remuneration report. A second strike this year would trigger a further vote on whether to spill the board and force all directors to stand for re-election.

Cynics say that, in this position, bank directors will act in self-interest rather than risk losing their lucrative board seats.

'There's no way (boards) want to risk a second strike' — Anonymous banker

"The board will act in the board's interest,'' shrugged one banker. "There's no way they want to risk a second strike, so they'll do whatever is required to avoid it."

Advertisement

Other bankers say the financial performance of all the major banks has suffered in the low interest rate environment. At the same time, the remediation bills of many banks continue to climb as their investigations into past misconduct have uncovered other problems.

The combination of lacklustre financial results and mounting compensation costs makes it all the easier for bank boards to justify taking an axe to senior executives' bonuses.

But some of the country's top directors are not persuaded that bank boards should blindly follow the CBA's lead.

They say CBA and NAB were subjected to the greatest shaming by the Hayne royal commission and Westpac and ANZ fared much better.

This puts Westpac chairman Lindsay Maxsted and ANZ chairman David Gonski in a much more difficult position.

(NAB's acting chief executive Phil Chronican, who took the reins following the abrupt departure of the bank's previous boss, Andrew Thorburn in February wisely decided to take fixed salary with no bonus entitlement).

Said one of the country's most highly regarded directors: "No doubt everyone's bonuses will be cut a bit. But I wouldn't be halving people's bonuses.

"I wouldn't be saying 'CBA has done it, so we should do it', because then how do you reward people for having done better?"

Advertisement

All the same, in the febrile atmosphere at present, bank directors could well decide that the most prudent course of action is to avoid further controversy by following the CBA's lead.
description: Already under attack over their failure to pass on official interest rate cuts in full, now the country's financial chiefs have a new source of angst
